questiontext.text:
Suppose that village B is {@AB@}km due east of village A. Suppose the bearing of village C is \({@bearac@}^\circ\) from village A and the bearing of C from B is \({@bearbc@}^\circ\). What is the distance between village C and B? Give your answer to the nearest km.

 

 

  • BC=[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]km

generalfeedback.text:
Recall that bearings are measured clockwise from true north. Hence angle x = \({@bearac@}^\circ\). Since village B is due east of village A we know that angle \(x\) plus angle A must add to \(90^\circ\). Hence angle \(A = 90^\circ - {@bearac@} = {@anga@}^\circ\).

Similarly, angle \(y\) must be \(360^\circ - {@bearbc@}^\circ = {@angy@}^\circ\) as the bearing from B to C is \({@bearbc@}^\circ\). Hence angle B is \(90^\circ-{@angy@}^\circ = {@angb@}^\circ\) (since we know village A is due west of village B). Finally, \[ \mbox{angle } C = 180^\circ -({@anga@}^\circ + {@angb@}^\circ) = {@angc@}^\circ. \]

In order to find the distance from village C to B we need to find the length of side CB. Therefore, we can use the sine rule to obtain \[ \frac{BC}{\sin {@anga@}^\circ} = \frac{{@AB@}}{\sin {@angc@}^\circ} \implies BC = \sin {@anga@}^\circ \left(\frac{{@AB@}}{\sin {@angc@}^\circ}\right) = {@ta1@} \mbox{ to the nearest km}. \]
